Dear Yulonda W Shell:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
08/20/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Rorie Dodge-Pifer at (517) 899-6024.
Sincerely,
Dayna Lamkey, MA, LLPC
Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to requirements; staff
qualifications
• (1) Child caring institutions subject to 42 USC 671 shall not permit a child
caring institution staff member to begin working unless all of the following
has been completed using the forms, and in the manner, prescribed by the
department:
• (a) A criminal record check as referenced in R 400.4113(f), including
a fingerprint based check of national crime information databases,
unless an alternative criminal history check has been approved by
the federal government.
1 of 21 employee files reviewed included DCWL notation of employee not being
e ligible for hire.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
2

• (1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and date an initial
treatment plan for each resident within 30 calendar days of admission.
2 of 3 youth files reviewed included an initial service plan signed prior to the end of
the 30-day reporting period.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
• (1) When a resident is discharged from institutional care, all of the following
information shall be documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
• (a) The date of and reason for discharge, and the new location of the
child.
1 of 3 youth files reviewed did not include any discharge documentation when
youth was discharged from one facility license to another.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Technical Assistance was provided to Human Resources to ensure staff are
checking the returned clearance forms to ensure DCWL has indicated an
employee is eligible for hire.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Consultation was provided to the facility to consider updating the Program
Statements to include any changes made to those programs for all of Vista
Maria's CCI licenses and to include types of youth served in each program in the
program statements.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 7 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: Special
Investigation 2025SIC0000135 with a CAP approval date of 3/20/2025 was a result
of a violation for youth not having activity access due to behavior of peers. The unit
managers will meet with staff to review activity expectations, in instances when the
3

building is experiencing crises situations, they will implement alternative activities.
The facility is currently complying with the CAP action steps and DCWL continues
to monitor CAP compliance with no noted concerns.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0001298 with a CAP approval date of 10/17/2024
was a result of a violation for youth-on-youth sexual contact. Staff reviewed client
supervision policy, staff 2 was counseled by leadership, and the facility updated
back to basics document. The facility completed this CAP on 6/24/2025.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0001230 with a CAP approval date of 10/10/2024
was a result of a violation of staff pushing youth and using derogatory language.
Staff 2 received counseling on appropriate interactions with youth, staff reviewed
behavior management policy and practices during unit meeting, staff member 2
attended CPI training, unit manager reviewed "tap out" guidance during unit
meetings, and leadership supported staff in implementation of tap out method. This
CAP was completed on 7/1/2025.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0001676 with a CAP approval date of 11/4/2024 was
a result of a violation of staff not following the approved restraint model. Staff 1 was
required to attend a CPI refresher, Staff 1 was required to shadow with a skills
trainer for one week, Staff 1 was to receive monthly coaching and Staff 1 was
suspended during the course of the investigation. Staff 1 was terminated effective
6/16/2024 and the CAP was completed on 7/24/2025.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0001551 with a CAP approval date of 9/25/2024 was
a result of a violation of a staff being hit by a youth and responding by hitting the
youth in the face. The behavior management policy will be reviewed during unit
meetings for 90 days and staff 1 was terminated from their position at the facility.
The CAP was completed on 6/24/2025.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0001775 with a CAP approval date of 12/5/2024 was
a result of a violation of the facility failing to follow their behavior management
policy. Staff 1 and Staff 2 were to attend a CPI refresher course and review
behavior management policy with leadership. This CAP was completed on
7/24/2025.
Special Investigation 2025SIC0000141 with a CAP approval date of 4/10/2025
was as result of a violation of staff failing to follow the facility behavior
management policy and staff making a threat towards youth. Staff 1 was to be
terminated, building leadership was to review employee behavior and behavior
management procedures, the director was to review video footage of critical
incidents to provide support, building leadership was to coach staff on the "tap out"
method, leadership was to monitor and provide coaching and feedback in the
moment when staff are observed not following policies, follow up was to be
completed on appliable critical incidences, and leadership was to ensure CPI
refreshers were done ever 6 months, The facility is currently complying with the
4

CAP action steps and DCWL continues to monitor CAP compliance with no noted
concerns.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and facility's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator Assessment was reviewed. The Chief Administrator reports
implementation of corrective action plans have been hindered by the reduction in
census and therefore in staffing. The facility has worked to provide additional
training to staff regarding policies and procedures.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff interviews were conducted during the inspection. Staff reported being eager
for more youth to be placed in the facility. Staff reported feeling supported by
administration however state that increased communication could be beneficial for
all levels.
Youth interviews were conducted during the inspection. Youth did not express any
concerns. Youth expressed excitement regarding the newly opened pool at the
facility. Youth did not report any concerns with staff. Youth reported enjoying being
able to do outings when they are available to them.
Description of Agency Walk Through
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of Beata Hall was completed on 8/18/2025.
There were no issues or safety concerns observed.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
